Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:

Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy Hill
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy was both accessible and very helpful in reviewing course material, he clearly knows his stuff really well.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy Hill.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: There is a fair amount of work for this class but it is valuable and worth it. The professor is very committed to the course and expects the same from the students.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The material was so well organized, it was easy to follow along. I liked the accountability in this class, being called on for readings was an excellent motivator!

The course was very well organized, covered a range of subjects concerning coastal ecosystems and did a good job of integrating biotic and abiotic factors of coastal ecosystems, as well as social aspects surrounding topics.
Reading scientific articles on a wide range of coastal issues and dissecting them in class; I feel much more knowledgeable about coastal ecosystems now.
Wonderful class. I really enjoyed the field trips and found them to be a valuable learning experience.

Shimi is a rock star. Such a great lecturer and somehow makes a 4 hour class interesting, engaging, and fun all the way through. I can never tell how he does it but I leave every class feeling like I learned a ton and didn't mind it in the least.The cookies and coffee break is clutch.The student presentations/papers were great. They let us explore our interests in more detail and I learned a lot from other people's presentations.The class size and community feeling of the class fostered a great learning environment- definitely my most close-knit class.The themes running through all ecosystems were well emphasized and were a great way to pull everything together.
Reading the primary literature and discussing the major points in class. I feel much more comfortable with journal articles as a result.
The variety it was not just Shimi lecturing all the time.
Great exposure to primary literature on coastal concepts. Nice discussions and student participation. Concepts were clearly explained.

The course material was presented clearly and questions and discussion was encouraged. I liked the amount of primary literature that I gained exposure to through the course. I think that it is useful to be able to analyze primary literature, and that is a skill that the students were able to hone through this course. The field trips were a great component as well and allowed for a synthesis of many of the concepts that we discussed in class.I also appreciated how we were able to ask questions on the readings via email before class. This allowed for a more streamlined class that focused on the areas where students had the most questions.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I thought it was a somewhat unfair disadvantage that we were expected to know redox and the N cycle. It would have been helpful to go over this a little more in class, or if you had an optional reading or session for students. I got by through the exams/quizzes, but still don't totally understand either.

As with any general course, we seemed to run through some subjects rather quickly. It may be beneficial to determine the most important subjects, perhaps based on an initial survey of people in the class in a given year, and go into a bit more detail on those fewer topics.
I don't think sending the weekly question was particularly useful. There could also be fewer quizzes.

Can we have a few more guest lecturers and/or field trips with these people? All four field trips were focused on salt marshes. While I know this is a big focus of the class, for those of us not as focused on SMs, I would have liked to go on a field trip to the rocky intertidal or a friday option to go out on the Sound.
Instead of having one student analyze/summarize a scientific article I think that it might be useful to have more discussions about them.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Excellent!
There was not a formal split between lectures and discussion-- rather they were more integrated which I enjoyed.
It was effective.
Good incorporation of lab material in lectures and vice versa.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy was overall a great TA, very willing to make time to meet and go over material. In general, he explained things well. My feedback would be on the N-cycle, as i went to office hours, and got the basics but still didn't understand enough compared to the level of understanding expected in the class. More preparation for an N cycle lecture would have been very helpful.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Although I did not interact with the TA much in this class, Troy was always accessible and willing to help.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy is great. Keep him around.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy was a great support to the class and has a lot of knowledge in the field. He was especially helpful with preparing for the final exam.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy was great and made himself available to students.

Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy was an accessible teaching fellow. He was always willing to meet with students outside of class, and he was great at explaining concepts. Before the exam he ran a review session that lasted about three hours to make sure that all of the students' questions were answered. He was a great teaching fellow.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Very important to my area of study.
I came to Yale to buff up my science knowledge and focus on coastal ecosystems, so this course met those needs exactly.

I am looking to a career in coastal management and conservation so this class was great. While salt marshes aren't my main focus, it was good to learn more about them and they were way cooler than I had thought. Wish FES had more classes on coastal subjects...
I am studying water resources management and I have a strong interest in coastal ecosystems, so this course fit well into my overall program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: One of the few coastal courses offered at FES
Interest in coastal areas but was lacking the biological perspective.
To learn more about the abiotic factors involving coastal ecosystems.
Interest in water resources.
I took this course because I had heard excellent things about it from the year before. It also fit well into my overall program of study.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!
Yes.
Yes
Would have liked a little more time spent on non-salt marsh topics but overall a great overview of many complex systems.

Yes. Even if I left with a lot of questions, the course showed me that ecosystem science is not straight-forward and there are a lot of interconnected processes at play. Also, the skill of reading and analyzing primary literature is very valuable.
Yes!
Yes. Expectations were met; very demanding course readings.
I learned even more from this course than I had anticipated. Difficult material was presented in an accessible way.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I liked how at the end of the semester, Shimi had us take 3-5minutes during class and discuss a graph or a topic. I think you should do that throughout the entire semester.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Keep up with the work load or it will overtake you. And it is worth it for the final to have done all the readings and have a good understanding of the material (these are not concepts you can just memorize).
It is not as much work as others may tell you or as you may think by the fact that it is 4 credits, and most of the work is great anyway!
take it!
TAKE IT. YOU WILL NOT BE DISAPPOINTED.
What I gained most from this class was not a bunch of facts about coastal ecosystems but an appreciation for the complexity of the issues facing these areas.
Shimi is a very detailed person and expects you to have a knowledge of the terminology of the subject or at least attempt to. Overall a great class.
Great class. Be prepared for a heavy workload. Very worthwhile for those with an interest in coastal ecosystems. Extra focus / attention paid to salt marshes of the northeast.
This is an excellent course to take. If you're interested in coastal management and water resources it will definitely be a worth-while course.
